posts.com: I've never felt this gutted in my life. I've known this guy since we were in college but we reconnected in late September. Since then we started to date here and there. Going out for dinner, doing fun activities but I needed a real conversation about where all of this dating was going. We had spent a good amount of time with each other so I felt like i wanted clarity on where all of this was going. I had a feeling that he did not want to commit but never in a million years did I expect to hear that I was basically too ''old''. His reasoning was that I was in my late 20s already, childless and single so my goal would be commitment and establishing a family before i would hit 30. He told me be that he needed way more time to commit to anyone and wanted to achieve some goals first and wanted experience life to the fullest before he could even think about a serious relationship. I could not believe what I was hearing. I told him that I was younger than him and that people grow together all the time (not that I was interested in growing with him after what he had said this but I was trying to make a point). He told me that even though he thought that I was pretty and smart that I would be in my 30's when he would seriously consider a serious relationship. I asked him if he was aware that he is aging too? That men age too? We ended having an ugly argument before we blocked each other. I'm sitting here and contemplating if my time is really up when it comes to dating and men? What do men look for? Am i really too old for dating someone in my age range or did he just not want me? I'm literally typing this with tears in my eyes. I can't control my age or time. I hate being a woman.

I've been with my wife for 10 years now, married for 4 of them. My wife and I have been friends with another couple for about 8 of those years (we all went to university together). Let's call them C (guy) and J (girl). During that time I've always been blown away by J's beauty and had a slight crush on her. Now C and J are married as well with 1 kid. J is a materialistic type of person, she likes nice things but because of the financial situation of her own job + C's business they aren't as well off as me and my wife, and sometimes she mentions to me how'd she love to be in the same position as us so she can go on overseas holidays or do house renovations like we have. Unbelievably yes. I'm 30, 5'9 and overweight so the girls I get aren't that hot (but all fuckable), but the fact I'm getting girls with some regularity is amazing. My whole 20s was such a desert of sex, getting laid like once a year even when I was in shape. I've learned my face is actually decent looking, but it never mattered because I was such a shutin and socially stunted (even with a good face I was never Chad tier hot where girls would chat ME up)

The keys have been
>cutting out the copes as much as possible
>study and practice (my biggest problem is going into sympathetic nervous response in lively settings people like to meet, but there are techniques to mitigate that I learned practice regularly)
>focusing on staying out of the house
>being the initiator for all things social. I introduce myself and chat with dudes at the mma gym, I pressure my friends into being less shutin, I think up all the places to go and activities. I'm the nexus of the social group bc everyone else seems fine treading water for the rest of their lives.
>talk to everyone in proximity, guys and girls, even if only for a single sentence about the weather. It helps.
>approach girls you like THEN look for signs, not the other way around
>pleasantly disengage if no signs, don't fight to keep convos going
>girls want FUN more than anything. It's the 21st century, they can take care of themselves (even if barely, in some cases), so being a stable provider isn't good in itself anymore. Social prowess, engaging convo, jokes, laughter, excitement is more important than ever.

posts.com:
>>28309285
>cutting out the copes as much as possible
Copes help subdue negative emotion. Negative emotion is actually your instincts' tool to compel you to action. Our brains are wired to conserve energy, so if it can reduce the negative emotion more efficiently, your prefrontal cortex will rationalize coping. Your instincts can't tell the difference and are sated, and you waste another day, week, month online. You'll face an avalanche of boredom, depression, anxiety. Weather it and find courses of action.
>sympathetic nervous response
Techniques I use in the moment that reduce physical symptoms of anxiety
-diaphragmatic breathing
- soften the gaze
-relax pelvic floor
-relax soft palette
-open up posture
-I just realized this week that chewing gum helps keep my jaw from clenching
At first it's tough going out and using these, because you have to remain conscious of every single breath and it's a bit demoralizing seeing how bad you are. Don't let up, go out frequently for a month practicing and it becomes more natural.
>approach girls you like THEN look for signs, not the other way around
Thought this was intuitive. Most guys stand around waiting for girls to give them signals of interest before they approach. That's a bad strategy because chances are you aren't attractive enough to stand out in a crowd to be noticed. If she's cute, you walk up and chat her up, and THEN see if she gives signs of interest.
>girls want FUN more than anything.
What more needs elaboration? Easiest route possible is to always have party drugs available, flash wealth, or be loud boisterous and cocky. Or get into scraps, if u got the guts (I don't lol but just saiyan)
>what do you find to talk about for conversations
Depends on context. Comment on surroundings, destinations, attire, attitude, and beyond that, FORD.

My first kiss in high school was with some girl who was into me on NYE. Afterwards I pretended not to be interested in her because I was afraid.

Other than a few times that girls came up to me cold and asked for my number, the only way I've ever gotten dates is through apps. On apps I usually get matches, but I'm a very boring texter and don't know what to talk about so they usually don't respond or ghost within a few messages or agree to a date and ghost the day of. >>28320523
>Set a clear goal of what you want to be able to draw
>Set a clear daily schedule
>Practice fundamentals and learn theory (set projects where you focus on improving a certain skill like perspective or shading)
>Have fun and draw what you want (even pros make mistakes and have something they can improve)

T. stoped drawing because I was afraid of it. I may come back to it. The thing is you are doing this for yourself. Not for validation from others, money, to be better than other artists or to hear how talented or good you are. It's just a fun thing to draw shit. You will suck for a long time and even when you become good you will still see mistakes and a thousand other artists who are better than you. Some of these are just talented and were drawing seriously for many hours every day for decades since they were young.

Don't fall into the trap of consooming videos and tutorials. Just fucking draw. Set some time to study the dry boring stuff like the fundamentals and doing still life but you should mostly be drawing what you want for fun. There is a lot of free pirated high quality courses and books on /ic/. You don't have the time to go through all and they won't make you a master artist. It comes down to drawing and doing exercises given in those courses.

>>28320523
The general outline of learning how to draw well involves understanding how to make lines look like something, an illusionist's trick. In order to do that you need to understand:
>Breaking down complex objects into simple forms so that you can understand them better
>imitate 3D form with perspective by utilizing curves and depth with larger/longer lines to simulate something being closer and smaller/thinner lines to simulate something being farther away
>understanding color and light theory to enhance the previous two's illusions.

With this mind, you should learn
>basic shapes
>perspective
>lights and shadows
>anatomy
>color theory
in that order, BUT and this is huge, while drawing what you like. You can't mindlessly grind fundies or else your interest wanes (unless you find grinding fundamentals fun), instead you should be learning these things in the context of what you like drawing. Utilize the shrimp method while you're at it too(https://www.deviantart.com/5019/art/Tutorial-How-to-draw-anything-352414195), as it encourages the usage of references, which you need to develop a mental library which will allow you to one day draw without references should you stay on the path. Good luck OP, I wish you well.

There's a shortcut to drawing decently in a short period of time.
Find two or three artists you really like that inspire you and copy as much of their work (without tracing) as you can. After a copying a good amount of drawings try to make something of your own with what you learned.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28322413
>Is it worth moving out
It's circumstantial so I'll run through a couple of scenarios, assuming you live somewhere that's kind of expensive eg a capital city:
>Moving out with friends
Yes, rent is often manageable if you're living with a couple of mates (2-3 others is best) and the freedom you experience is intoxicating. When people say high-school is the best time of your life, include the couple of years after high school when you're just having fun with your friends and learning life. Even if you're on struggle street for a little, as long as your friends are hard-up as well it really isn't an issue because you all manage together. Bonus points if you have a goal during this time like finishing university.
>moving out with strangers
60/40, if you get a good house it can be almost as good as above, if you get shitty housemates you'll be more miserable than when you're at home. Bonus points if you're living near other friends while doing this.
>moving out on your own
Rarely worth it if you can still do everything you want to do while at your parents. Rent is way too much and you're going to struggle until you're earning properly. If you can't do what you want while living with your parents (either too far away or too strict parents) then this can still be okay but it's not a care-free lifestyle since you've got such high overheads with rent and bills. My advice is sus-out with friends a potential living arrangement and work towards that in the mean time.

Moving out at 19 with some friends from the country to the city for university kicked off some of the most fun years of my life, even at 29 I look back fondly at 19-24

depends on who you were before, who you are now, and who they were and are. if you've genuinely changed, it's best to be honest and real, don't bother fronting cuz it'll show through. don't carelessly pry but do try to show a genuine interest in them. I never ask about work, love life, living situation, or other potentially sensitive topics unless I pick up that they want to talk about it or that it's at least not gonna be a sore spot. Unless you don't mind things getting unpleasant, idk, it depends on how close you were before. It would suck to ask if there's a mrs. or "hey how's "x"" "oh we broke up" or some shit like that, or like, ask how work is out of the blue and see their fucking neck tense up just thinking about it. Ask about their old hobbies, try to bring up topics that are relevant to your immediate situation "sure are a lot of people out tonight" or "where is everybody", get conversation going that way. it's totally fine to dip into the nostalgia memory lane tank but try not to rely on it because it sucks when you meet up with old friends and realize the only thing you have left in common is the past.

I didn't talk to people much for my early twenties but I had a little renaissance and got better at it, so I've been where you are, but being a good conversationalist means reading the mood and letting it flow, just use your oars to steer clear of the rocks but don't go there loaded with question cards or plan shit out because it will always quickly deviate from them and leave you at a loss for words. Ask questions about them, let them talk, and when they stop talking or you have something to say, jump in with follow up questions or your own input, but if you sense that they're bored, try to segue it into something else, or just completely left field. Sorry for rambling and vagueness, but it really is a personalized thing and skill set that comes with experience. good luck OP hope you have fun :)

I will say that while it often feels like it's out of the blue, often the other person has actually been thinking about it for a while (boy or girl), which gives them a strong head-start in the healing process. It's easier to move on when you've been mentally laying the groundwork for 6 months.
Things are going to hurt for a long time, don't be afraid to see a therapist so you can talk shit out without becoming too much for your friends and a doctor can prescribe something that will help with sleep if you can't. See friends as much as you can and take this opportunity to expand your social circle when you're up for it. Don't rush into casual sex or another relationship unless you want to, casual sex can be liberating for some or just a reminder of how shallow sex is without emotion.

I don't want to be trans per se, I was really scared at first once I realized I might be transgender. I know society will make things a lot harder for me, some people will want to harm me or make my life difficult because of it, and I don't know how my family will react.

But my whole life I've hated my body and the way I look even though I know I'm not ugly and there's nothing wrong with me. Ever since I was young I've felt an intense jealousy of beautiful women. Not just that I'm attracted to them, but I wish I could be them. I wish I could look beautiful like they do and wear feminine clothes and makeup and do my nails and have girl friends to hang out with as girls. I've always felt this way but for the longest time I thought it was just one more thing to suppress to try and hide how abnormal I am.

But I don't want to live like this forever. I can't. I can't spend the rest of my limited time on this earth hating my body and my voice and not wanting to associate any of my work with my birth name. I only recently started trying feminine clothes and makeup and it's a night and day difference, all of a sudden I feel comfortable in my body and I love the way I look and I feel like me. I know 100% for sure that I'd like to live the rest of my life as a woman and I don't care what the consequences are. I don't know if I will still be able to pass starting transition in my late 20s, though it's still possible because I have a trans friend online who started her transition at my age and passes pretty well. Even if I can't, I'd rather be an ugly woman than a man when I'm 30.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>> I'm 28 and I have no direction in life
>> Blah blah blah sob story
>> What do

Get some direction in life. I'm not going to suggest occupations to you because I don't know you so I have no clue what you are and are not good at/what your personality and temperament are like.

What I will tell you is that whilst you float around aimlessly you'll never get anywhere. You'll just tread water. So you need yourself a career goal. The skills shortage list in your country (every OECD country publishes one) is as good a place as any to start. Those are jobs in short labour supply, so there is little to no competition and they often pay extremely well.

Another thing to consider is careers counselling. These can be seen through most institutions of higher learning, sometimes they're free, sometimes they cost money it just depends on where they are. They'll do some standard testing with you (it's personality based not academic) and determine the kinds of jobs you're best suited to. They won't say "do this job" or "enter this industry". Instead they'll give you a list of careers that might work for you and ask what you think. You pick out a few you might be interested in and they're connected in to the education providers, apprenticeship schemes, etc so they can help you get sorted for any qualifications you need for those occupations.

However you go about it, the point is to find YOURSELF some direction. Once you have direction and start working towards your goals, other things will start to fall into place.

30 year old wizard here.
I learned at some point that reintegration requires a genuine comparability of your personality with whoever you're talking to. You can't be friends with everyone.

Go outside and walk in any direction and try to ask random people on the street if they want to go to the movies. That doesn't make any sense right? Instead you have to go where you actually want to be and then make a smart decision on how to connect in that place.

I am constantly trying to be friends with people and the message I usually get is that "life is cruel and you don't know how this works". I try to make positive connections and people try to make me frustrated.

I think wanting positive connections in life is not a fantasy, but it's okay to be a loner. I think being unhealthy and constantly engaging the same thing is bad, but the key to your life is happiness and that is not often found in social connections with strangers.

You aren't a loser if you don't connect with people, you just aren't connected, but feel free to connect with whatever makes sense with you, provided it isn't turning you into a mummy.

>>28321532
That hole in the middle of the doorknob is a keyhole. A tiny flathead screwdriver from a cheap glasses repair kit will most likely unlock it. If this is your door from the inside, tell the landlord to flip the doorknob. In addition to the privacy concerns, you can also get locked in during a fire which is a huge hazard that he's ultimately responsible for unless he flips it. The exception being if that's a bathroom with another entrance where whoever's inside wants/needs the privacy. Most niggers breaking in don't carry that type of screwdriver so they'll be loud enough to hear.
An outward-swinging door is harder to break into as the door stop (ridge along the jamb that prevents the door from swinging both ways) would also need to break. If it's a solid enough door that they can't just pull hard enough to pop it out or charge straight through it, you'd be safe. With a basic inward swinging door that lacks a deadbolt like that, some solid kicks above the knob will usually brute force it open.

>Well by that I just mean it would be better for her to not do that
Well, yes, but what I meant to ask about were the metrics you use for "good".
For me, the things I value most are stability (preserving things, be they relationships like marriage or things like animal species) and happiness (more in the sense of contentment--being satisfied with what one has, which implies no suffering). And I judge rules by how they work for these values in society, because moral rules are basically about how people relate to one another.

For example, doing away with notions of commitment entirely is horrible because it's destabilizing and more likely to make people miserable. Or like what you said, men hurting/degrading women, *even if the women claim to like it*, is wrong because no social rule can allow that while also preserving respectful relationships between the genders.

Values are the simple axioms about good or bad that you accept. Morals are social rules which objectively implement a given set of values. And ethics are situational applications of morals. At least, this is how I think of it, to describe my thoughts logically and systematically. Part of what you seem to be doing ITT is using them without much distinction, and it comes off as abrasive and even unhinged if you tell anyone who doesn't instinctively share your (as-yet-unspoken) values that they're not just wrong but illogical/stupid.

> This world is actually awful and unless you’re insanely rich bringing people into it seems pretty cruel.
Pretty close to what I think. One quote that stuck with me, although I don't know who said it, is that "history is just an endless record of unpunished crimes".
I hold out hope that there's some point in existence besides escape, that things can be "fixed", but it's hard for me to justify bringing anyone into the mess before that.

>Are shrooms and weed even comparable?
not really. weed has such a massive gamut of experiences for people. for me i smoked with the wrong crowd in high school and they always fucked with me which made me incredibly paranoid on it. plus it makes you shovel any food in sight down your throat like you're a robot. i generally don't really like weed.

with shrooms, it seems like people more or less get the same things out of it. i've done them twice and they were 2 distinct experiences. first time it was a light dose. it's an incredible euphoric body high, kinda like opiates, but you don't feel tired. your colors are also enhanced. it's basically like you have HDR turned on for your brain. i remember i watched aladdin 4 times that night. i couldn't turn away from the colors, i was enthralled. i thought it was the most sublime movie experience ever.

2nd time i did it was a proper dose and a more traditional trip. get ready to see things, lots of things. you can still see reality, but you will also be seeing a lot of other things. i was at a beach during the day so i saw all kinds of shit come out of the ocean. the trip comes in "waves"; you get this slowly building experience of visuals that will crescendo and then STOPS, everything is then serene for a little bit and it will build up again. each one gets stronger and stronger until you "peak" about 3 hours in, then successive waves reduce in intensity after that. you will feel mentally drained after the trip.

also something else unique to weed: you will get a stomachache. you will probably have to shit. you are poisoning yourself after all. it will subside after a little bit though.

>>28320218
Where were your migraines expressing themselves? Over the eyes? Back of the head? Temples?
How's your sleep? Are you getting 8+ hours a night?

Anything canned with acidic foods, especially tomatoes should not be used. With your condition being as it is I would try to rule them out altogether. In this situation your endocrine has become somewhat pathological and it's probably an entire environment's worth of factors that have brought this state about.

The endocrine system is a network of organs throughout the body all of which work to maintain a hormonal homeostasis. If even one of these organs is in stress it stresses the rest of them out as well and if the environmental issues are not resolved a pathological homeostasis takes form which creates a normal state of unhealth. The problem, once this happens, is that to break an existing homeostasis requires a sharp shock to it. So you may have to make some drastic changes in order to turn things around.

Here are a few of them, there are more but these are the most important:

Vitamin D3 deficiency is a worldwide epidemic. Vitamin D is not really a vitamin, it's a prohormone and it plays myriad of roles throughout the entirety of our organism. You may want to get a blood test which tests for both the active and inactive form of vitamin D to see where your levels really are. Regardless, with most people being deficient I strongly suggest supplementing with 5000-10,000IU a day especially during the winter and the times where you're not getting sunlight. Vitamin D3 should be taken with K2 as vitamin K2 ensures that the vitamin-d associated calcium ends up where it's needed and not in the areas where it can induce trouble. As for a supplement, I recommend the Dr. Berg brand as it's the cheapest combo with U.S. made ingredients.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28320794
The liver is a secondary organ in the endocrine system but its role should not be written off. When you take NSAIDs regularly, which is particularly common for women with painful menstrual cycles, you begin to deteriorate your liver's capacity. Since you're having so many recurring migraines I can only imagine how often you rely on these to get through the day. To stop taking them is probably not an option, nor would I want you to suffer. But what you should do is chase every NSAID with at least 600mg of N-Acetyl-Cysteine, preferably Pure Encapsulations brand as they're a U.S. manufacturer that doesn't use Chinese ingredients. NAC helps replete the master antioxidant glutathione within your liver which NSAIDs rapidly deplete. Chronic use of NSAIDs will keep your liver in a perpetual state of unhealth by suppressing glutathione levels which can, over time, exacerbate and further allow this pathological homeostasis of your endocrine system to persist.

From what I'm observing based off what you have provided you are expressing multiple symptoms of estrogen dominance. This can be overcome but to break the current homeostasis requires a shock. The strongest shock you can provide, in my opinion, is fasting. I think a 3 a day water fast every month for 4-6 months might be exactly what you need to start recovering. If you are the type of person that eats three meals a day you may want to work yourself to one meal a day before going for a three day fast. To go from three meals a day to no meals a day is really difficult for people doing their first multi-day fast. You can do it, it's just more stress on the body than it would be if you were already eating one meal a day.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28320800

Second, you're going to want to get an intracellular magnesium and potassium test as these are the electrolytes that are most often related to estrogen dominance and glandular function. You need to specifically ask for an intracellular test for these electrolytes as they are intracellular electrolytes (98-99% are within your cells). If you rely upon a blood serum test you're not going to be able to adequately diagnose a deficiency until its in its latest stages. For some, magnesium can make migraines worse so use caution with them. I would start with magnesium glycinate and then work from there if that form of Mg induces migraines. Try to find a form of magnesium that does not stimulate migraines if you can, don't give up if the first brand/type you try induces them. For potassium I recommend buying Dr. Berg's electrolyte powder as it has 1000mg of potassium (4,700mg is the recommended daily intake) per scoop. It's the most affordable way to supplement with potassium that I have found. Most potassium in the diet comes from vegetables so you may want to try to figure out how much you need to supplement with to ensure you're meeting your dietary requirement.

Third thing you're going to want to do is clear the body out of heavy metals which you have been accumulating throughout your life. The safest way to do this is by way of Modified Citrus Pectin. 5mg/3x/day for 1 month (PectaSol / Econeugenics brand) should clear the majority of what can be cleared out minus what has been sequestered in bone of course. As a side note, I would also ditch any teflon cookware that you have and replace them with cast iron, ceramic, stainless steel or carbon steel.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28320807
Next you will need to deal with your drinking water issue. Bottled water inevitably leaches chemicals from the plastics even if it's a BPA-free plastic. I recommend dropping money on a distilled water system and adding your own trace minerals to it or using electrolyte powders to get the needed electrolytes. The brand of distiller I recommend is the My Pure Water brand:

https://mypurewater.com/shop/mini-classic-ct-distiller/

I own this one myself and it's a great machine; it's easy to maintain and only requires a once a month cleaning to keep going. If you're making soups, broths or use water for boiling to make rice/pasta then I would also invest in an undersink filter to filter out your municipal water, especially fluoride which is notorious for wreaking havoc to the endocrine system (I'll get to fluoride more in a second). The system I use is this one:

https://www.amazon.com/Frizzlife-SK99-NEW-Certified-Chlorine-Chloramine/dp/B08NDYVZV5/

As for fluoride, I would immediately stop using fluoride toothpastes. I would also be mindful of any canned foods packed in water (often packed in municipal fluoridated water) and if you can get a flouride-rated shower filter that would be helpful as well. The problem with fluoride is that it accumulates as it's readily retained at a rate of 35% - 50% of that which is ingested (younger people retaining more than adults). And when fluoride gets retained it gets sequestered in bone. The presence of iodine triggers its release and removal and there has been some brewing hypotheses regarding using iodine as a way of treating long-term fluoride toxicity.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Anyone here who had eye laser surgery and would like to share their experiences? I'm considering getting eye laser surgery myself, because I generally hate having to take care of my glasses, and I somehow feel more confident about my appearance without glasses.
After the surgery, will your eyes last like that forever? I am more interested about experiences in the long run, people who have had their eyes lasered for years.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28319785
I had relatively bad nearsightedness (needed -6.0 correction) and some astigmatism. Lasik surgery was in feb 2020.
Left eye has perfect vision still, right is between -.25 and -.50 now. I have quite dry eyes, right is worse in that regard and it gets annoying. I think there's some nerve damage that has not healed, if I get something in that eye it's hard to get out, there's almost no tears. My vision in dark is a bit worse and I see halos and "stars" around many light sources. Driving at night is not too enjoyable.
Despite of lingering negatives, I'm happy. I was completely useless without glasses before. Now I can fucking see. It's ridiculous how much my life improved. I can exercise without glasses fogging or disturbing. My face looks better. Everyday things are much easier. 8/10 result, would choose surgery again. Night vision issues (lights) are the worst downside, but that doesn't happen to everyone.
>will your eyes last like that forever?
No, your vision might not stay perfect. Even if it does, farsightedness is possible when you age.

If you have bad nearsightedness (over 5.0) I absolutely recommend laser surgery if possible. I know 3 people IRL who have had it (besides me) and all are happy. Operation costs quite lot but if you need specialty lenses for your glasses, you'll save money in the long run.
This might sound over hyping. However, getting my eyes operated is genuinely one of the best decisions I have made in my life and I only regret not going earlier. I was 30 at the time of surgery.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I had this surgery 8 years ago so i'm not sure if anything changed, but my doctor offered me two kinds of procedure: the first could leave side effects, like making you see some stains when you're in dark rooms or making you more photosensitive (cheaper, but the healthy insurance would cover 100% of the costs), and the second was double the price but was less likely to leave any side effect and had faster recovery. I paid for the second one.

The first week after the procedure was pretty unconfortable. I had to take multiple painkilles and wear sunglasses 24/7. After that everything was fine, and it's still fine today. From what i've heard, you won't have any issues before you get old and your vision begin to strain like most people. Also, in my country there is a minimum age you need to be to be legal to go through this king of surgery. You should check that up.

As a side note: some people say that if you wear glasses for many years it stops being an accessory and starts being a part you yourself. And i think i agree with that. I'm not sure if you're going to be more confident after surgery, but i can confirm your personality will change a bit.

>>28319785
You need glasses when you get older like everyone else, mostly for reading. Still 20/20. It also fixed my lazy eye but they can’t guarantee those.

I had trouble opening my eyes wide enough for them to scan everything. That was the only annoying thing prior to the surgery.
The surgery itself Was pretty uncomfortable. Once they cut your eye and flip the flap up you don’t see anything. And then you get it with a kaleidoscope of green and red. And they send you off with a little sunglasses that you’re supposed to wear forever. The pain afterwards was mainly like having an onion rubbed in your eye any aftercare is kind of annoying just constantly putting drops in. But I slept most of it.
Then I had to go back either the next day or the day after I can’t remember, and I went out without glasses and I went into the alley and I saw a mouse getting chased by a cat, and I realized I was watching this all with my natural eyes which was really cool.

I have a weird job right now, but I enjoy it. I've been working as my brother's caregiver for the last four years. He's developmentally disabled (nonverbal, poor fine motor skills) and epileptic so he can't really support himself. My mom caught me at the right time when the second guy she hired to do this before me quit; I was feeling pretty aimless, bouncing around retail jobs from when I graduated high school up to that point.

I'm leaving the job later this year since I don't want to spend my whole life in my hometown, but I'm probably going to find work at a group home or something once I do.
